title.narrative: Improving Nutrition and Feeding for Mongolia's Most Vulnerable Children

description.narrative:
In the fall of 2014, SPOON and WVI conducted an initial needs assessment among families with CWD in Ulaanbaatar to identify training needs among caregivers and HVs in feeding and nutrition and opportunities for impact. Activities included using SPOON’s Short Assessment of Feeding Environments (SAFE) tool on vulnerable children, focus group discussions and interviews with parents and caregivers, home visits with families of vulnerable children, and meetings with a variety of stakeholders (i.e., Disabled People Organizations, family clinic staff). The findings revealed a gap in knowledge, attitudes, practices and support for caregivers around feeding for CWD, including prevention of malnutrition, lack of adaptive equipment, and improper feeding practices related to positioning, food texture, spoon-feeding and cup feeding. Family clinics appeared to lack capacity to monitor growth and anemia for CWD.
SPOON is currently working with WVI to design and implement a ToT on improving feeding for CWD for WVI’s Home Visitors and stakeholders and develop and launch a growth and anemia monitoring system in family clinics.

This project aims to identify needs in feeding and nutrition practices among vulnerable families and provide them with critical training and support. To this end, SPOON and World Vision International (WVI) are developing and piloting a training program for Home Visitors (HVs) in feeding and nutrition practices for families of children with disabilities (CWD) in Mongolia.
